CatDescriptText: Mr. Joseph Simpson, retired, Squirrel Hill and Mr. Robert Steen, O'Hara Township, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 1, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe in capital punishment?  If not, what type of punishment do you suggest for those who commit what is generally termed "vicious murder."  Mr. Simpson's answer reads:  I do believe in it in some cases, for instance in the case of a gangster who would be better off out of this world.  And i believe in it for other persons who commit vicious and pre-mediated crimes."  Mr. Steen's answer reads: "It depends on the cars as a rule, but as a general principal.  I don;t approve of i.  as I said, the circumstanced under which the murder was perpetrated would determine whether or not the death penalty should be used.  Generally, I don't think it solves too much.  It is were retained, it might make people think twice. But, no matter how you look at capital punishment, I don't like it."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Joseph Simpson wearing medallion patterned scarf and flecked overcoat, standing in front of Sherwin Williams store, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Robert Steen wearing light colored grid patterned shirt, standing in front of C.A. Michel, Smithfield Street, Downtown
